#gender 1 = male, 0 = female

source.0ecbf9af:
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score, KFold
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.naive_bayes import GaussianNB
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
source.82b2cc99:
# prepare models
models = []

models.append(('LR', LogisticRegression(random_state=10)))
models.append(('NB', GaussianNB()))
models.append(('DT', DecisionTreeClassifier(random_state=10)))
models.append(('RF', RandomForestClassifier(random_state=10)))

accuracies = []
names = []
stds = []

#loop through all models
for name, model in models:
    kfold = KFold(n_splits=10, random_state=10)
    validateResults = cross_val_score(model, X, Y, cv=kfold)
    
    accuracies.append(validateResults.mean())
    stds.append(validateResults.std())
    names.append(name)

#store results in dataframe
resultsDf = pd.DataFrame({
    'model': names,
    'accuracy': accuracies,
    'std': stds,
})
source.fe45a660:
#plot mean accuracy and standard deviation
resultsDf.plot('model', style='.-', figsize=(10, 5))

plt.xticks(range(len(resultsDf['model'])), resultsDf['model'])
plt.show()
source.1089fb67:
There are two values in Gender:
* F = Female
* M = Male
 
Most importantly, data distribution is balanced(50% of male and 50% of female samples). What is balanced data distribution? Let me explain using this example. If in our data set we have male samples which are approximately the same as female samples, then we can say our dataset is balanced. On the other hand, if there is a very high difference between the male samples and female samples, then we can say our dataset is imbalanced.

"Imbalanced classifications pose a challenge for predictive modeling as most of the machine learning algorithms used for classification were designed around the assumption of an equal number of examples for each class. This results in models that have poor predictive performance, specifically for the minority class. This is a problem because typically, the minority class is more important and therefore the problem is more sensitive to classification errors for the minority class than the majority class." (Brownlee, 2019).

Handling imbalanced data is whole another story. Therefore, I'm not going to discuss it here. However, I would like to attach some articles here for your reference. 

* https://machinelearningmastery.com/what-is-imbalanced-classification/
* https://machinelearningmastery.com/failure-of-accuracy-for-imbalanced-class-distributions/
* https://towardsdatascience.com/handling-imbalanced-datasets-in-machine-learning-7a0e84220f28

Ok, Now we have some idea about the target variable. Let's study next variable,

#### 2. Favorite Color

source.5429bc16:
According to above results, we can see that non of any model is able to provide accuracy higher than 60%. Among them, the Naive Bayes model is able to provide the highest accuracy 58.8% with a standard deviation of 27%. The standard deviation shows us, how precise the estimates are. This means in our case that the accuracy of our model can differ +-27%. I think the reason for the low accuracy is the size of the dataset. Therefore, if we need to achieve better results, I believe that we have to provide enough data.

Hope you've enjoyed my work, if you like my work and need to share something with me leave a comment :)

Data Pre-Processing
Let's convert all categorical variables into dummy variables. I use One-Hot Encoding to convert all variables since all of them are nominal.
source.46a45a25:
This dataset is a very small dataset and it contains 66 samples and 5 variables including the target variable. We can see that all the variables are categorical. Furthermore, all of them are nominal which means there is no order in the data.
Missing Data Aanalysis
source.0332f1d8:
Variable "Favorite Music Genre" contains seven values: 

* Rock - 28.7%
* Pop - 25.7%
* Hip hop - 12%
* Electronic - 12%
* R&B and soul - 9%
* Folk/Traditional - 6%
* Jazz/Blues - 6%

The highest number of participants like to listen to Rock music. Most of the male participants like to listen to Hip hop, Electronic, R&B, and soul and most of the female participants like to listen to Pop and Jazz. Surprisingly, a higher number of female participants have mentioned that their favorite music genre is Rock when compared to male participants. 

#### 4. Favorite Beverage
source.b1455843:
Variable "Favorite Beverage" contains six values: 

* Doesn't drink - 21.2%
* Beer - 19.6%
* Other - 16.6%
* Wine - 15.5%
* Vodka - 13.6%
* Folk/Traditional - 6%
* Whiskey - 13.6%

The highest number of participants do not drink and most of them are male participants. When compared with male participants higher a number of female participants like to drink Wine, Whiskey, and Other beverages. On the other hand, male participants like to drink Vodka and Beer. 

#### 4. Favorite Soft Drink
source.9fe439be:
According to above graph, we can see that: 1. Generally, participants who like to drink Coca Cola/Pepsi like Vodka, Wine, and Beer. 2. Most of the participants who like to drink Fanta also like to drink Whiskey.
Small Dataset and Overfitting
The goal of a machine learning model is to generalize patterns in training data so that you can correctly predict new data that has never been presented to the model. In other words, we need to find a good balance between bias and variance such that it minimizes the total error. ![](https://miro.medium.com/max/700/1*9hPX9pAO3jqLrzt0IE3JzA.png) Models trained on a small dataset tend to overfit and produce inaccurate results. Therefore, we have to avoid overfitting but how do we do it? we can use the below techniques: * [Use simple models](https://hackernoon.com/7-effective-ways-to-deal-with-a-small-dataset-2gyl407s) * [Remove outliers from data](https://www.kaggle.com/rafjaa/dealing-with-very-small-datasets) * [Select relevant features](https://hackernoon.com/7-effective-ways-to-deal-with-a-small-dataset-2gyl407s) * [Ensembling Techniques](https://towardsdatascience.com/breaking-the-curse-of-small-datasets-in-machine-learning-part-1-36f28b0c044d) * [Cross validation](https://elitedatascience.com/overfitting-in-machine-learning)
source.9694b715:
